content.text: Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 1.1 where the mass \(m\) is \(200 \text{g}\)
Use the Blu- Tack to attach the protractor to the edge of the block along the \(90^{\circ}\) line
Use the ruler to ensure that the wooden rod is directly above the edge of the block as shown. Clamp the block to the bench with the G- clamp
The boss should be clamped tightly to the stand to prevent the rod from rotating

Adjust the height of the boss so that the spring is perpendicular to the wooden strip. Use the set square to check that the strip and spring are perpendicular to each other by placing it gently as shown in Fig. 1.2. Any contact of the set square with the strip will cause the apparatus to move
Measure and record the length \(L\) of the coiled part of the spring as shown in Fig. 1.2
Measure and record the angle \(\theta\) between the strip and the vertical line on the protractor as shown in Fig. 1.1
Change \(m\) and repeat **(b)** until you have five sets of values of \(m\)**,** \(L\) and \(\theta\)**.**
For each set of readings the spring and strip should be perpendicular to each other
Include values of \(m \sin \theta\) in your table
Plot a graph of \(L\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(m \sin \theta\) on the \(x\)-axis
Draw the straight line of best fit
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line
gradient =
y-intercept =
The quantities \(L\) , \(m\) and \(\theta\) are related by the equation
where \(P\) and \(Q\) are constants
Using your answers in (d)(iii), determine the values of \(P\) and \(Q\). Give appropriate units
In this experiment, you will investigate how the extension of a spring depends on the load applied to it
Tie one of the lengths of string into a loop of circumference approximately 40cm
Measure and record the value of the circumference of the loop
circumference = .........
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of the circumference
percentage uncertainty = .........
Tie the other length of string into a loop of the same circumference
Measure and record the value of the circumference of the loop
circumference = .........
Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 2.1
Both rules should have their markings facing you
The strings should be looped over the metre rule and support the half-metre rule
The strings should be vertical, \(25\mathrm{cm}\) apart and equal distances from the centre of the lower rule
Move the end A of the half-metre rule towards you and the end B away from you. Release the rule and watch the movement
End A of the half-metre rule will move away from you and back towards you, completing a swing
The time taken for one complete swing is \(T.\)
By timing several of these complete swings, determine an accurate value for \(T.\)
Repeat **(b)** with the half-metre rule at the top and the metre rule supported by the strings
Repeat **(b)** with the \(30\mathrm{cm}\) ruler supported by the strings
Copy the data from the card
Using your data from (b)(ii), (c)(i) and (c)(ii) and the data on the card, calculate three values of \(k\)
first value of \(k =\)
second value of \(k =\)
third value of \(k =\)
Justify the number of significant figures that you have given for your values of \(k\)
Explain whether your results in (d)(ii) support the suggested relationship
It is suggested that the relationship between \(T\) and the mass \(m\) of the supported rule is
where \(k\) is a constant assuming the loops are of equal circumference. The value of \(T\) also depends on the value of this circumference
Describe four sources of uncertainty or limitations of the procedure for this experiment
Describe four improvements that could be made to this experiment. You may suggest the use of other apparatus or different procedures
In this experiment, you will investigate how the motion of a rule depends on its mass
